journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Mathematical modelling of the pneumatic relay emergency valve for dual-line agricultural trailer braking systems

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Bialystok University of Technology, ul. Wiejska 45C, 15-351 Białystok, Poland. email: z.kaminski@pb.edu.pl

abstract.p: A mathematical model of the trailer relay emergency valve used in the pneumatic braking systems of agricultural trailers has been presented. The differential equations of the model allow for the inertia of control elements, static and kinetic friction, and heat exchange in individual valve chambers. The developed mathematical valve model was used for simulation of the transient processes in the dual-line braking system of a single-axle agricultural trailer. The computer models for individual components of the braking system were made within the program MATLAB/Simulink in the form of S-function-type functional structural blocks based on original algorithms. The positive results of validation of the trailer braking system computer model show a potential for a wider use of dynamic computations in the computer-aided process of designing pneumatic vehicle braking systems.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Pneumatic multi-circuit braking systems are commonly used in rail and automotive vehicles [1–3] as well as in agricultural vehicles [4]. Because of road safety, braking systems must meet several specific requirements for braking performance and high-speed operation during rapid braking (the reaction time should not exceed 0.6 s) and must provide follow-up control operation and the synchrony of work of individual circuits [5].

The basic elements of pneumatic braking systems are filters, couplings, valves, and brake chambers interconnected into a functional system with pneumatic lines. In addition, braking systems include mechanical, electric, hydraulic, or information technology elements (an anti-lock braking system (ABS) or an electronic braking system), which together form a complex heterogeneous engineering system [6]. Interaction between the various components of the braking system, as well as interaction of the braking system with other vehicle systems, can be analysed at an early stage of design by using digital simulation methods.

Relevant studies on the modelling of pneumatic brake systems in the literature focus mainly on the areas of ABS [7–9] and fault diagnosis [10, 11]. The analysis of the pressure transients in the brake system, especially in the brake chambers, is also important to model the longitudinal dynamics of the vehicle during braking where, in addition to simple first-order linear models of the pneumatic brake system [12–15], non-linear models are increasingly used [16, 17]. For the purpose of digital simulation of the longitudinal dynamics of the vehicles during braking and, in particular, vehicles equipped with an ABS, transient tyre models are being developed [18, 19].

The ability to calculate the dynamic characteristics by simulation methods is extremely important during the design process of new pneumatic brake systems, as it allows its behaviour during normal and rapid operation or malfunction to be predicted without the need to conduct expensive laboratory tests [20]. Through selection of the best construction parameters of lines, valves, and other devices of a braking system made on the basis of an analysis of the system’s dynamics, a reduction in the time of the transient processes in the system, on the one hand, and an enhancement of the synchronicity of braking the hauling vehicle and the trailer, on the other hand, will be achieved.

Owing to the discrete nature and complexity of braking systems and the need to execute all system components within a specific programming environment, even systems of parameters distributed in a continuous manner, such as pneumatic lines, are substituted in mathematical modelling with models of lumped parameters (i.e. discretized) [21]. As a result, ordinary differential equations are obtained, which are able to be solved within a majority of specialized programs designed for digital simulation of complex engineering systems, including object-oriented programs [9].

In the process of modelling pneumatic elements, line filters or fasteners (e.g. couplings or T-connections) are substituted by idealized elements in the form of lumped volumes and resistances [20, 22]. The modelling of braking systems is much more difficult, especially when considering the equations of motion for the control elements [23–26]. This paper presents a method for the mathematical modelling of pneumatic braking valves in the example of a trailer relay emergency valve. The mathematical and computer model of this valve considers a number of phenomena, such as heat exchange, the inertia of moveable elements, and friction, which have generally already been omitted at the stage of physical creation or at the stage of running the computer model for digital simulation [10, 27, 28].

The model may be useful in analysing the dynamics of pneumatic braking systems and in the design process of a relay emergency valve at the stage of dynamic calculations, following static calculations [29].

sec.title: 2 Construction and Operation of the Valve in a Dual-Line System
sec.p: A schematic diagram of a typical dual-line braking system of a single-axle agricultural trailer is shown in Fig. 1. The diagram and its description contain the actual data and parameters of the real braking system used for the experimental studies described later in the paper.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of a trailer dual-line pneumatic system (the designation is according to the DIN 74253 standard): 1, supply coupling; 2, control coupling; 3, line filter (Haldex 81.01.010.0); 4, trailer relay emergency valve (Petoletka Trstenik 5.213.02.700.0) with a hand apportioning valve (Visteon 61.11.012.0); 5, air reservoir (20 dm3); 6, membrane brake chamber (Haldex type 20LS); length of flexible spiral tubes Lz = Ls = 4.5 m (inner diameter of 9 mm); length of flexible tubes Lzv = 0.28 m, Lvb = 6.5 m (inner diameter of 12 mm)

sec.p: The trailer’s braking system is connected with the hauling vehicle’s braking system using supply coupling 1 and control coupling 2. For activation of the trailer’s brakes, braking valve 4 is used. A schematic diagram of the construction of the valve, which can operate both in a single-line system and in a dual-line system, is given in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the trailer braking valve: 1, control piston; 2, inlet head; 3, outlet head; 4, head spring; 5, piston return spring; 6, piston with a lip seal; 7, piston rod; 8, internal piston

sec.p: In the dual-line system, the valve chamber of volume V1 (Fig. 2) is connected with the supply line, the chamber of volume V4 with the control line, the chamber of volume V12 with the trailer air reservoir, and the outlet chamber of volume V2 with the brake chambers. The braking valve has a piston tracking mechanism (pistons 1 and 8) and two heads: inlet head 2 and outlet head 3.

During braking, the airflow
m
·
4
from the control line flows into the chamber of volume V4, causing a pressure increase p4. Under the action of the differential pressure, piston 1 travels downwards together with the small piston 8. After piston 8 has reached head 3, the atmosphere outlet port closes, while head 2 opens the inlet port from the inlet chamber of volume V12 to the outlet chamber of volume V2. Compressed air from the trailer’s reservoir flows into the inlet chamber (mass flowrate
m
·
12
) and then to the outlet chamber of volume V2 (mass flowrate
m
·
12 − 2
) and to the brake chambers. The increasing pressure under piston 1 causes both the pistons with the head assembly pressed on by the return spring 4 to move upwards to the mounting of head 2 in the seat. Closure of the inlet port causes the pressure in the outlet chamber of volume V2 to stabilize. The tracking action of the valve depends on the balance of forces acting on the assembly of pistons 1 and 8.

During a brake release, the pressure in the chamber drops (this time, the mass flow rate
m
·
4
flows out from the chamber of volume V4), and the assembly of pistons 1 and 8 moves upwards. This closes poppet valve 2 (cuts off the inlet chamber from the outlet chamber) and opens the outlet port of the chamber of volume V2 to the atmosphere. Compressed air from the brake chambers flows into the outlet chamber as the mass flow rate
m
·
2
(flow reversal) and then flows out to the atmosphere (the mass flow rate
m
·
2 − 3
) through the vent.

sec.title: 3 The Mathematical Model of the Valve
sec.p: When creating the current mathematical model of the trailer relay emergency valve, a number of simplifying assumptions were made, including the following.

list-item.p: Compressed air is regarded as a thermodynamically ideal gas (i.e. it obeys the Clapeyron law), while being viscous and compressible.
The valve-adjusting element, irrespective of its construction, is regarded as a local resistance (nozzle), whose effective flow field (conductance) depends on the head lift.
The airflow through the adjusting element is regarded as one dimensional and adiabatic.
The air properties are uniform both in the individual valve chambers and in the entire cross-section of flow through the local resistance.
In the valve opening phase, the force interaction between the head and the control piston is omitted, which means that both elements move together as a single mass (one equation of motion).
The air leakage in the valve chambers is neglected.
The influence of the housing on the control piston in its end position is neglected; stopping of the piston is accomplished via acceleration control logic (hard stopping).
Heat exchange between the system’s air and the environment takes place by natural convection at a constant wall temperature which is equal to the ambient temperature.

sec.p: In accordance with the law of conservation of matter, the changes in masses in the valve chambers (Fig. 2), i.e. the control chamber of volume V4, the supply chamber of volume V1, the inlet chamber of volume V12, and the outlet chamber of volume V2, are described by the equations

where
m
·
i
is the mass flowrate (kg/s) flowing into (the sign +) or out from (the sign −) a given chamber; the respective flow subscripts conform to the convention on denoting the braking valve chamber couplings (the small numerals at the valve couplings in Fig. 1).
For the description of the mass flow rate of air flowing through the local pneumatic resistances, the Saint-Venant–Wantzel relationship was utilized, with the general form

where (µAm) is the conductance, i.e. the product of the discharge coefficient µ, and the flow cross-section area Am (m2), pm is the pressure (Pa) upstream of the resistance, Tm is the air temperature (K) upstream of the resistance, R is the gas constant for air, which is equal to 288 J/kg K, and Ψmax is the maximum value of the Saint-Venant–Wantzel function for the critical product σ* of the pressures upstream and downstream of the resistance, which is given by
where κ is the adiabatic exponent which, for air, equals 1.4.
Instead of the dimensionless two-range Saint-Venant flow function Ψ(σ) given by

the more convenient form for numerical computation and, at the same time, sufficiently accurate single-range hyperbolic function used by Metljuk and Avtushko [22] and Miatluk et al. [30] was employed and is
A constant parameter value of b = 1.13, which is typical of the pneumatic elements used in the braking systems of vehicles, was assumed.
Using equation (5), the equations of mass flows flowing through the braking valve are obtained as

The reduced mass of the elements moving together with the piston is

and the Clapeyron equation in the differential form
after performing the necessary transformations, the differential equations for the variations in the pressure and the temperature in individual valve chambers are obtained as

where Ui is the internal energy (J) of air in a given chamber, Hi is the enthalpy (J) of the flux flowing into (+) or flowing out from (−) a given chamber, Wi = −pi dVi is the external work (J) done by the air in the chamber, and Qi is the heat (J) exchanged with the environment.
Heat exchange between the air in the ith chamber and the environment occurs by natural convection at a constant wall temperature (which is equal to the ambient temperature) and is given by

where αi is the heat transfer coefficient (W/m2 K) of the ith chamber, Ai is the internal area (m2) of the ith chamber, Tw is the valve housing wall temperature (K), and Ti is the temperature (K) of air in the ith chamber.
The heat exchange area and the volumes of some chambers depend on the piston displacement hp and on the mode of valve operation. Thus, for operation in the dual-line system
where A is the internal area (m2) of the chamber and V is the chamber volume (m3); the areas and volumes with zero at the end of the subscript correspond to the initial values.

sec.title: 4 Example of Simulation of the Trailer Braking System
sec.p: For validation of the computer model of the valve, as well as the models of other pneumatic components, the results of experimental tests on a dual-line braking system (Fig. 5) built on the basis of the T654 trailer by Pronar [32] were utilized. In the trailer system tested, a different length of the line in the transmitting circuit was employed, namely Lvb = 6.5 m.

caption.p: General view of the stand for dynamic testing of the braking system built from the components of the T-654 trailer braking system by Pronar

sec.p: The computer model of the tested trailer braking system was created in the form of S-function-type graphical subsystems written in the m-files of the MATLAB/Simulink program. For the purposes of computer model validation, From Workspace-type input blocks were added. With their use, actual time variations of the actuator piston rod displacement xe (a link encoder), and pressure variations (pressure transducers), as recorded during the experimental tests at the points of the system, as indicated in Fig. 1, were input to the computer model. These included the following: the pressures pse and psve at the beginning and end respectively of the control line (upstream of the coupling and upstream of the valve respectively), the pressures pze and pzve at the beginning and end respectively of the supply line, the pressure pzbe in the trailer’s reservoir, the pressure pre downstream of the apportioning valve, and the pressure pbe in the brake chamber.

Sample simulation (solid curves) and experimental (dashed curves) test results obtained during checking the response time of the braking system of the trailer tested are presented in Fig. 6. The agreement between the time function graphs of the experimental pressure pbe and the simulated pressure pb in the brake chamber, which are important in view of the purpose of the tests, was confirmed by Kolmogorov–Smirnov test results (at a significance level of 5 per cent) and a high value of the coefficient of determination of R2 > 0.99, used for evaluation of the degree of matching of both graphs. The obtained results on validation of the trailer braking system computer model are also indirectly indicative of the suitability of the mathematical and computer braking valve model for simulation of the transient processes occurring in the braking systems of vehicles.

caption.p: Results of simulation of the transient processes in the braking system of a single-axle trailer: (a) in the control and supply circuits: (b) in the transmitting circuit. The symbols have the following meanings: for the experimental pressure (dashed curves), phe is the pressure in the hydraulic system of the simulator (i.e. the pressure actuating the relay emergency valve), pze and pzve are the pressures at the beginning (upstream of the coupling) and at the end (upstream of the valve) respectively of the supply line, pse and psve are the pressures at the beginning and at the end respectively of the control line, pzbe is the pressure in the reservoir, pre is the pressure downstream of the apportioning valve, pbe is the pressure in the brake actuator chamber; for the model pressure (solid curves): p1 and p4 are the pressures in the supply chamber and the control chamber respectively of the valve, pzb is the pressure in the reservoir, pr is the pressure in the outlet chamber of the apportioning valve, and pb is the pressure in the actuator chamber; xe and x (dotted curves) are the experimental piston rod travel and the simulated piston rod travel respectively; v is the piston rod travel speed

sec.title: 5 Summary
sec.p: In the described mathematical model of the trailer relay emergency valve, the real course of phenomena accompanying the operation of braking valves has been taken into account to a considerable extent. The formulated differential equations of the variations in the air pressure and the air temperature in individual valve chambers consider the heat exchange with the environment, which has generally already been omitted at the stage of constructing physical models of valves. The differential equation of piston motion, on the other hand, takes into account the static and kinetic frictional forces and the inertial forces, which are often neglected when constructing computer models of valves, because of the instability of numerical solutions. Based on the described trailer braking valve model equations, mathematical and computer models for other braking valves of similar construction can be created.

The example of the trailer braking system model, described and executed within the MATLAB/Simulink program, indicates a potential for a more extensive use of dynamic computations in the computer-aided process of designing multi-circuit pneumatic vehicle braking systems with a view to developing the desired dynamic properties, including the speed and synchronicity of action.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: Ai internal area of the ith chamber (m2)
Am flow cross-section area (m2)
cv stiffness of the spring (N/m)
Dsp average diameter of the moveable seat (m)
Dsv average diameter of the stationary seat (m)
Dsvw inner diameter of the stationary seat (m)
Dt inner diameter of the head sleeve (m)
Dw outer diameter of the head sleeve (m)
Dz diameter of the head sleeve guide (m)
fc, fs kinetic frictional force and static frictional force respectively per unit piston perimeter, independent of the differential pressure across the piston (N/m)
Fcv guide kinetic frictional force (N)
Fe sum of the external forces acting on the moving mechanical system (N)
Ffp force of piston 1 friction against the housing (N)
Fp4−2 force of pressure acting on pistons 1 and 8 (N)
Fsvo spring preset force (N)
Fv force of head 3 pressure on piston 8 (N)
ho maximum distance (clearance) between head 3 and piston 8 in the upper extreme position (m)
hp control piston position (m)
hpm piston position in which the flow field attains the maximum value (m)
hpo piston position corresponding to the beginning of opening the passage to the atmosphere (allowing for plate seal deformation) (m)
hv distance of the head from the valve seat (m)
hvm valve plate position corresponding to attaining the maximum flow field value (m)
hvo valve plate position corresponding to the beginning of opening (allowing for plate seal deformation) (m)
